Example of lightweight feature documentation üìÉ

https://alisterbscott.com/2020/05/29/example-of-lightweight-feature-documentation/

I‚Äôm not keen on writing specifications in gherkin (Given/When/Then) as I think it‚Äôs too generic and frequently makes the feature specifications too verbose ‚Äì and takes emphasis away from the critical parts.

The important thing to note is the actual documentation artifact generated isn‚Äôt as important as the collaborative process that is involved in generating it. This is often about asking the right questions and adding more examples until there‚Äôs nothing that is unclear.

The document isn‚Äôt a template ‚Äì the actual documentation varies based on conversation, problem and context.

Example: Royalty Payment Splits

Background

  • Royalties need to be paid in full on disbursement to artists.
  • A royalty payment can be made to an individual artist, or a group of artists.
  • When making payments to an individual artist they get 100% of royalties (no rounding) When making payments to a group of artists this needs to be split by the percentage splits defined in the system which always add to 100%
  • When splitting a payment across a group of artists and it doesn‚Äôt split evenly into cents, the system currently randomly splits the cents between artists to balance out the rounding over time
  • This causes issues for both automated tests which need deterministic behaviour, and artists who are confused why they get slightly different amounts if their royalties are the same.

Scenarios / Examples

ScenarioRoyalties OwedCurrent Royalties PaidNew Royalties PaidTesting
Single artist gets 100% of whole payments$100.00$100.00$100.00‚úÖ
Single artist gets 100% of payments including cents$66.67$66.67$66.67‚úÖ
Two artists with 50% each for a payment that can be split evenly$100.00artist 1: $50.00 artist 2: $50.00$50.00‚úÖ
Two artists with 50% each for a payment that can‚Äôt be split evenly$100.01$50.01 / $50.00 is randomly assigned to artist1/artist2artist 1 $50.01 artist 2 $50.00‚ùå
Two artists with 50% each for a payment that can be rounded to ten cents ‚Äì no rounding$100.30artist 1: $50.15 artist 2: $50.15artist 1: $50.15 artist 2: $50.15‚úÖ
Three artists with third splits can‚Äôt be split$100.00amounts of $33.33, $33.33 and $33.34 randomly assigned to group membersartist 1: $33.34 artist 2: $33.33 artist 3: $33.33‚ùå
Three artists with third splits can‚Äôt be split ‚Äì more than a single cent difference$100.00amounts of $33.33, $33.34 and $33.34 randomly assigned to group membersartist 1: $33.34 artist 2: $33.34 artist 3: $33.33‚ùå

Business Rules

  1. Royalties need to be paid in full on disbursement to artists.
  2. A single artist gets a whole payment.
  3. When payments can be split evenly to a group of artists (to the cent) they are split that way.
  4. When payments can‚Äôt be split evenly to a group of artists, the payments are split into an even split and the remaining cents are distributed to the members in whole cents.
  5. The first member in the group ‚Äì based on earliest date/time added to group ‚Äì gets the higher amount, followed by the second, third etc. based on earliest date/time added.
  6. Payments aren‚Äôt rounded to ten cents or five cent amounts, only whole cents

Questions/Decisions

QuestionDecisionMade By
Do we want to round to five or ten cent distributions?No, we‚Äôll always round to the centProduct Owner via Slack ##
How do we distribute based on membership of group?We‚Äôll use the date time added to the group (first gets most)Team during kick off meeting

Summary

I think trying to force the above information into gherkin (Given/When/Then) statements would make it less readable and provides no added benefit ‚Äì whilst Given/When/Then encourages consistency sometimes you just need structured thought that is most relevant to your context. The above document isn‚Äôt a template ‚Äì it varies for the problems we‚Äôre trying to solve.
